column4: Is there a possibility to change the default internal-browser? (nautilus)?
it's possible, but very painful. If you don't like nautilus, you may as well switch away from gnome. Have you tried KDE and Xfce?
- No, never tried any of them.
you can get a full alternative environment with apps installed with 'sudo apt-get install kubuntu-desktop' (for KDE)
- How would this effect my current installation?
not at all, provided you have enough disk space. You will be able to choose the environment each time you log in.
- Oh, well. What are the diffrances?
Xfce is lighter and thus better for lower-end machines, sacrificing some convenience. KDE offers more tweaks and some would say it's closer to Windows designwise.
the difference is best experienced, though. Alternatively, see if you can get an impression from Youtube videos
- Well, it sounds like I'm good with Gnome i think, I just wanted to check if there was a possibility to change it, to try others. I know there are some good.
you can try some in parallel with nautilus. Really replacing, ie. removing nautilus will break a lot of things, though
- Sounds like I'm not really ready to try that, heh.
are you any good on the command line? If you're at all technically inclined, you'll still fare much better with that than with graphical file management.
- Well, I do handle alot of stuff through the terminal, but I prefer a simple GUI controlled one.
- Well, I'm trying out some alternatives right now, I find PCMan File manager quite okay.
- I like the tabbing features and the customization feats.
